questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Pyruvate carboxylase

B. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxy kinase

C. Hexokinase

D. Pyruvate kinase

E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A and E only

 

Gluconeogenesis bypasses the three irreversible steps of glycolysis using four specific enzymes. From the given options, only two are actual gluconeogenic enzymes. Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria, requiring ATP and biotin as cofactor. This is the first step in bypassing the pyruvate kinase reaction. Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which allows glucose release from liver and kidney cells. This enzyme is absent in muscle, explaining why muscle cannot contribute glucose to the bloodstream despite having glycogen stores.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (A, B and E only): "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" is not a real enzyme - this appears to be a nomenclature error. The actual gluconeogenic enzyme is phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), which converts oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

 

Option B (B and C only): Neither enzyme participates in gluconeogenesis. "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" doesn't exist, and hexokinase catalyzes the forward glycolytic reaction (glucose → glucose-6-phosphate), consuming ATP rather than producing glucose.

 

Option D (A, B and C only): This includes both the non-existent "phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" and hexokinase, which is a glycolytic enzyme that would oppose gluconeogenesis by converting free glucose back to glucose-6-phosphate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among the listed enzymes, only pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are genuine gluconeogenic enzymes that help bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis to synthesize glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

 

The test used for the detection of ketone bodies (KB) in the given scenario of a 15-year-old boy with type I diabetes mellitus is Rothera's Test.

 

Rothera's Test involves the reaction of acetoacetate with sodium nitroprusside and glycine in an alkaline medium. This reaction forms a purple-colored complex, indicating the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benedict's test is used to detect the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, in a solution.

 

Option C. Seliwanoff's test is used to differentiate between different types of sugars, particularly distinguishing ketoses from aldoses.

 

Option D. Biuret test The Biuret test is used to detect the presence of proteins in a sample by reacting with peptide bonds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.

 

In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies is associated with sexual maturation defect and hypogonadism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zn (Zinc)

 

Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a critical role in numerous biological functions, including growth, immune function, and reproduction. Zinc deficiency is associated with several clinical manifestations, among which hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation are prominent. Hypogonadism refers to a condition where the body does not produce enough sex hormones, which can lead to delayed puberty, underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics, and infertility.

 

The deficiency of zinc impairs the normal functioning of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, leading to decreased production of testosterone in males and estrogen in females. This hormonal imbalance is directly linked to the symptoms of sexual maturation defects observed in zinc-deficient individuals.

 

Zinc also plays a significant role in wound healing, immune function, and DNA synthesis. Its deficiency can lead to delayed wound healing, impaired immune response, and chronic diarrhea, further exacerbating the clinical picture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selenium: Selenium deficiency is primarily associated with oxidative stress-related conditions, such as Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy). It is not typically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Option C. Cu (Copper): Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, and neurological issues but is not linked with hypogonadism or delayed sexual maturation. Copper is involved in iron metabolism and the functioning of several enzymes but does not directly impact the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron deficiency is well-known for causing anemia, particularly microcytic hypochromic anemia, and can lead to symptoms such as fatigue and weakness. While severe iron deficiency can impact overall growth and development, it is not specifically associated with hypogonadism or sexual maturation defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is directly linked to hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturation, along with other symptoms such as impaired wound healing, decreased immunity, and chronic diarrhea. Recognizing and correcting zinc deficiency is crucial for preventing these clinical outcomes.

questions.text: Methyl tetrahydrofolate accumulation and functional deficiency of folate is seen in the deficiency of: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vit B12

 

Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for DNA synthesis and plays a role in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to its active form. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to the functional deficiency of folate because it impairs the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl tetrahydrofolate, leading to the accumulation of the latter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid: Folic acid, also known as vitamin B9, is a crucial vitamin required for DNA synthesis, cell division, and various metabolic processes. In cases of folic acid deficiency, methyl tetrahydrofolate can accumulate, but there is no direct deficiency of vitamin B12. Folic acid deficiency primarily affects folate-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Vit B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not directly related to the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate. It primarily plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism as a cofactor for enzymes involved in the citric acid cycle.

 

Option D. Vit B6: Vitamin B6, also known as pyridoxine, is involved in various enzymatic reactions, including those related to amino acid metabolism. It is not directly associated with the metabolism of folate or methyl tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To understand the metabolic consequences of vitamin deficiencies, medical students should recognize that the functional deficiency of folate, characterized by the accumulation of methyl tetrahydrofolate, is primarily seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, making it important to distinguish between the two deficiencies in clinical practice.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to accumulation of methyl THF. Free THF becomes deficient (Folate Trap) and as THF is functional form of folate it is also known as functional deficiency of folate.

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 536

choices.text: Collagen is a type of fibrous protein, which is most abundant of all human proteins
Post translational hydroxylation of proline & lysine
Triple helix is required for its function

questions.text: Which of the following is false about collagen: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most abundant AA is Phenyl-alanine

 

Collagen is a fibrous protein that is indeed the most abundant protein in the human body. It provides structural support to various tissues, including skin, bones, tendons, and blood vessels. However, the most abundant amino acid in collagen is actually glycine, not phenylalanine. Glycine makes up approximately one-third of the amino acids in the collagen protein chain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Collagen is a type of fibrous protein that is the most abundant protein in the human body. It forms a strong and flexible structure in various tissues.

 

Option C. Post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues is an essential process in collagen synthesis. This hydroxylation is necessary for the proper formation and stability of collagen's triple helix structure.

 

Option D. The triple helix structure is a characteristic feature of collagen and is crucial for its function. Collagen molecules are composed of three polypeptide chains, coiled around each other in a triple helical arrangement. This structure provides collagen with its strength and stability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the correct composition of collagen is essential to understand its structural role in the human body.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: Which of the following defects causes familial hypercholesterolemia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL receptor

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is primarily caused by a defect in the LDL receptor or Apo B100 protein. The LDL receptor plays a crucial role in the regulation of cholesterol levels in the blood by mediating the uptake of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) particles into cells, particularly in the liver. When the LDL receptor is defective or absent, LDL particles cannot be effectively removed from the bloodstream, leading to elevated cholesterol levels, which predispose individuals to atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease. This condition is also known as type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo E: Defects in Apo E are associated with type III hyperlipoproteinemia, not familial hypercholesterolemia. Apo E is important for the clearance of chylomicron remnants and VLDL from the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Apo CII: Apo CII is an activator of lipoprotein lipase, which is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides in lipoproteins. Deficiency in Apo CII leads to type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial hyperchylomicronemia), characterized by elevated chylomicrons and triglycerides, not familial hypercholesterolemia.

 

Option D. Apo B48: Apo B48 is involved in the formation and secretion of chylomicrons from the intestine. It is not related to the development of familial hypercholesterolemia, which involves defects in the LDL receptor or related proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor, leading to elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood and increased risk of atherosclerosis.

questions.text:
You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence.

 

  1. Lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria
  3. SDS-PAGE
  4. Hybridization
  5. Protein elution/extraction
  6. Expression of protein

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

 

Explanation:

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology for expressing a gene of interest for production of a desired protein in E. coli cell.

 

The steps of Recombinant DNA technology are:

 

  1. b) Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria: The gene of interest is inserted into a vector such as a plasmid, which is then introduced into the host E. coli cell to produce recombinant E. coli.
  2. f) Expression of protein: The recombinant E. coli is grown in a suitable medium to express the protein inside the cells.
  3. a) Lysis of bacterial cell: The bacterial cells are lysed to extract the expressed protein.
  4. c) SDS-PAGE: The extracted protein is purified using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis.
  5. d) Hybridization: The protein is identified and confirmed by western blotting or hybridization.
  6. e) Protein elution/extraction: Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted for subsequent use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

References: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 432-438

questions.text: Most preferred chromatography for HbA1c? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ion-exchange chromatography

 

  • Ion-exchange chromatography is the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis that separates molecules based on their charge.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis,

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrophoresis:

  • Electrophoresis is a technique that separates molecules based on their charge and size.
  • It is not the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis because it may not provide the specificity and accuracy needed for precise quantification of glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Affinity chromatography:

  • Affinity chromatography separates glycated hemoglobin based on its specific affinity for a stationary phase that can selectively bind to HbA1c.

 

Option D. Immuno turbidimetry:

  • Immuno turbidimetry is a technique that measures the concentration of substances in a solution based on the degree of turbidity.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis, it may not be as specific as affinity chromatography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methane

 

  • Methane does not inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • Cytochrome C oxidase is primarily inhibited by substances that interfere with the electron transport chain, such as cyanide and carbon monoxide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. H2S (Hydrogen Sulfide):

  • H2S can inhibit cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It is a known inhibitor of this enzyme and can disrupt mitochondrial respiration.

 

Option C. CO (Carbon Monoxide):

  • CO is a potent inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the same heme groups in the enzyme's active site as oxygen, preventing oxygen from binding and disrupting electron transport.

 

Option D. Cyanide:

  • Cyanide is a strong inhibitor of cytochrome C oxidase.
  • It binds to the iron in the enzyme's heme groups, blocking the transfer of electrons in the electron transport chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CN, CO and H2S are inhibitors of Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV of ETC). They inhibit by non-competitive inhibition and this type of inhibition is mostly irreversible. For a complete list of ETC inhibitors refer to table below:

 

Inhibitor of ETC complexes

 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 123

questions.text: FISH is used to detect all of the following except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is a cytogenetic technique that allows for the detection of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It is particularly useful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities such as translocations, amplifications, deletions, and aneuploidies (such as trisomy or monosomy). These alterations are detectable because they involve large-scale changes in the chromosomal structure or number that can be visualized using fluorescent probes.

 

However, FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations. Point mutations are changes at the single nucleotide level, which are too small to be detected by this method. Point mutations require techniques that can analyze DNA sequences at a higher resolution, such as PCR-based methods, sequencing, or allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translocation: FISH can detect translocations, which involve the rearrangement of chromosome segments between nonhomologous chromosomes. This can be visualized by the hybridization pattern of fluorescent probes.

 

Option B. Amplification: FISH is effective in detecting gene amplification, where multiple copies of a particular region of the chromosome are present, resulting in an intense signal from the corresponding fluorescent probe.

 

Option C. Deletion: FISH can identify deletions, including microdeletions, by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the DNA sequence is missing from the chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is a cytogenetic technique used to detect chromosomal-level changes such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions but is not capable of detecting point mutations at the nucleotide level

questions.text: DNA-Protein interactions can be studied by using: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA footprinting

 

  • DNA footprinting is a technique used to study DNA-protein interactions. It involves the selective cleavage or modification of DNA sequences by a DNA-binding protein. By analyzing the resulting pattern of cleavage or modification, researchers can determine which regions of the DNA are bound by the protein, effectively "footprinting" its interaction sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA fingerprinting: DNA fingerprinting is a technique used to identify individuals based on their unique DNA patterns, primarily in the context of forensic science and paternity testing. It is not specifically used to study DNA-protein interactions.

 

Option C. Northern Blotting: Northern blotting is a molecular biology technique used to study gene expression by analyzing the presence and quantity of specific RNA molecules in a sample. It is not primarily used to study DNA-protein interactions but rather RNA-related processes.

 

Option D. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): ELISA is an immunological assay used to detect the presence of specific antibodies or antigens in a sample. While it can indirectly provide information about protein-protein interactions, it is not a direct method for studying DNA-protein interactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DNA footprinting is the appropriate method for studying DNA-Protein interactions, as it allows researchers to identify the specific binding sites of proteins on DNA by selectively cleaving or modifying the DNA sequence. This technique is fundamental for understanding how proteins interact with DNA in various biological processes.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 451

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence 5'GATCTAC3'. What is the base sequence of RNA product? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'GUAGAUC3'

 

Explanation:

 

You're given the template strand of DNA:


5′–GATCTAC–3′

 

But remember:

 

  • Transcription reads the DNA template in the 3′ → 5′ direction
  • So we must first reverse the strand to get its 3′ → 5′ orientation
    3′–CATAGTC–5′

 

Now, perform complementary base pairing to make the RNA strand (synthesized 5′ to 3′):

 

 

So the RNA product is:


5′–GUAGAUC–3′

 

Educational Objective

 

The complementary base pairing rules are:

 

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).

 

The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Human genome project?  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It took 2 years to discover

 

  • Explanation: Option D is false. The Human Genome Project did not take only 2 years to complete. It was a long-term endeavor that spanned over a decade. The official launch of the project was in 1990, and a working draft of the human genome was announced in 2000. The project was completed in 2003.
  • Relevance: This statement is false, and the actual timeline of the Human Genome Project demonstrates that it was a multi-year, collaborative effort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collaboration of Many Countries:

 

  • Explanation: The Human Genome Project was indeed a collaborative effort involving many countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Japan, and others. It aimed to map and sequence the entire human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects the international nature of the project.

 

Option B. 20,000 Total Genes Were Identified :

 

  • Explanation: During the Human Genome Project, it was estimated that there are approximately 20,000-25,000 protein-coding genes in the human genome. This estimate is relatively accurate, considering the complexity of the human genome.
  • Relevance: This statement is true and reflects one of the significant achievements of the HGP.

 

Option C. It Uses Modern Sequencing Techniques:

 

Explanation: 

 

  • The project initially started with Sanger sequencing, which was state-of-the-art at the time.
  • Towards the end and afterward, next-generation sequencing (NGS) evolved, further enhancing genome studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Human genome project started in 1990 and completed with sequence of Y chromosome this year in 2022. So, it took > 2 decades. This was a collaborative project spread across many labs in different countries across world. Approximately 22000 genes were identified in entire Human genome using High throughput Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) techniques.

 

Reference: Harper’s 30th ed/pg- 98

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachidonic acid

 

Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid found in cell membranes. Arachidonic acid serves as the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis when it is released from membrane phospholipids through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2. Once released, arachidonic acid can be metabolized into various eicosanoids, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet aggregation: Platelet aggregation refers to the process of blood platelets clumping together. While eicosanoids can influence platelet aggregation by promoting or inhibiting it, they are not formed directly from platelet aggregation. Platelet aggregation involves the activation of platelets and the release of various signaling molecules, including some eicosanoids, as part of the clotting process.

 

Option C. 4 fused rings: Eicosanoids are not characterized by having four fused rings. Instead, they are typically small molecules with a 20-carbon backbone structure.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not directly involved in the formation of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are primarily derived from arachidonic acid, as mentioned earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 224

choices.text: High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid
Hemolytic anemia is a feature
B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate
Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.text: In folate deficiency, the False statement is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemolytic anemia is a feature

 

Folate deficiency primarily leads to megaloblastic anemia, which is characterized by large, immature red blood cells (macrocytes) in the bone marrow and blood due to impaired DNA synthesis. Folate is crucial for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, the building blocks of DNA, which is why DNA synthesis is directly affected.

 

  • High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels increase because folate is required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. However, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal, which helps differentiate folate deficiency from vitamin B12 deficiency, where methylmalonic acid levels are elevated.
  • B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is recommended because both vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies can lead to similar hematologic manifestations, like megaloblastic anemia. However, treating a patient with folic acid alone when they have an undiagnosed vitamin B12 deficiency can mask the hematologic symptoms while allowing neurological damage to progress. Therefore, it is safer to supplement both B12 and folate unless B12 deficiency has been ruled out.
  • Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: Folate is essential for the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines, which are necessary for DNA replication. Specifically, folate is involved in the transfer of one-carbon units during the synthesis of these nucleotides. In its absence, DNA synthesis is impaired, leading to megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High homocysteine and normal methylmalonic acid: This statement is true and correctly describes the biochemical changes in folate deficiency.

 

Option C. B12 supplementation is recommended along with Folate: This is a true statement and an important clinical practice to avoid masking B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected: This statement is true because folate is directly involved in nucleotide synthesis, which is critical for DNA replication and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia, not hemolytic anemia. It is associated with high homocysteine levels and normal methylmalonic acid levels, and folate is essential for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, which are necessary for DNA synthesis

questions.text: A patient with C/O muscle weakness came to OPD. Doctor found he has cardiomyopathy & diagnosed him to be a case of Barth syndrome, where patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiolipin

 

Barth syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects males and is caused by mutations in gene responsible for the production of an enzyme involved in cardiolipin synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lecithin is a common phospholipid found in various tissues and cell membranes, but it is not specifically associated with Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option C. Lysolecithin is a derivative of lecithin that is formed when lecithin is hydrolyzed. It is not directly related to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Option D. Cephalin is a term that refers to a group of phospholipids present in cell membranes, but it is not specifically linked to Barth syndrome or mitochondrial dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiolipin is a unique phospholipid primarily found in the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a crucial role in maintaining mitochondrial structure and function.
  • The defective cardiolipin affects several mitochondrial processes, including energy production, electron transport chain function, and mitochondrial membrane stability. 
  • C/f
    • Muscle weakness
    • Neutropenia
    • Cardiomyopathy

choices.text: Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for protein precipitation? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

 

Protein precipitation is typically achieved using methods like alcohol, acetone, or trichloroacetic acid, or by changing the pH to the protein's isoelectric point (pI).

 

Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heavy metals: Heavy metals are not typically used for protein precipitation. They are more commonly associated with toxicity and contamination in biological samples rather than being used as precipitants.

 

Option B. Alcohol & acetone: Alcohol and acetone are frequently used for protein precipitation. They are added to protein solutions to denature proteins, causing them to precipitate out of the solution.

 

Option D. Trichloroacetic acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is commonly used for protein precipitation. It is an acidic compound that can effectively precipitate proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoelectric pH, protein’s net charge is zero, known as Zwitterion. This structure is insoluble, so precipitates out. At acidic pH, protein has positive charge.  At alkaline pH, protein has negative charge. 

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 19

questions.text: Glycosylated Hb (Hb-A1c) is best detected by: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ion exchange

 

Ion exchange chromatography is a highly effective method for detecting glycosylated hemoglobin (Hb-A1c). This technique separates hemoglobin molecules based on their net charge differences. Hb-A1c, which is glycated hemoglobin, has a different net charge compared to non-glycated hemoglobin. As a result, it can be quantified accurately using ion exchange chromatography. This method is widely accepted and used in clinical laboratories for monitoring long-term blood sugar control in diabetic patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Affinity chromatography: Affinity chromatography relies on the specific binding between a molecule of interest and a ligand immobilized on a chromatography column. While affinity chromatography can be used for various biomolecular separations, it is not the method of choice for detecting Hb-A1c. The affinity column would need to have a specific ligand that binds selectively to Hb-A1c, and this approach is less commonly employed compared to ion exchange chromatography for this purpose.

 

Option C. Isoelectric focussing: Isoelectric focussing is a technique that separates proteins based on their isoelectric points (pI), which is the pH at which a protein carries no net electrical charge. While this method can separate different hemoglobin variants based on their pI values, it may not be as precise as ion exchange chromatography for quantifying Hb-A1c specifically, as it relies on charge differences related to pI rather than glycation.

 

Option D. Electrophoresis: Electrophoresis is a general technique for separating molecules based on their charge and size differences in an electric field. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can separate different hemoglobin variants, including Hb-A1c, based on their charge differences. However, it may not provide the same level of specificity and accuracy as ion exchange chromatography when it comes to quantifying Hb-A1c.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPLC based methods are gold standards for measurement of Hb-A1c. These methods further include ion exchange and affinity chromatography-based methods of which Ion exchange method is considered as the best and widely used method followed by affinity chromatography and enzymatic and immunological methods.

 

Ref- https://www.japi.org/v264/hba1c-result-does-it-depend-upon-the-testing-methods-

questions.text: Which fusion exocytosis complex is affected in tetanus?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synaptobrevin

 

Synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein), is one of the proteins involved in the SNARE complex, which plays a crucial role in mediating vesicle fusion and neurotransmitter release at the synaptic cleft. In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin specifically targets and cleaves synaptobrevin, preventing the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine. This leads to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Snap 25: SNAP-25 (synaptosomal-associated protein 25) is another component of the SNARE complex involved in neurotransmitter release. It is not directly targeted by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option C. Syntaxin: Syntaxin is a third component of the SNARE complex, and like SNAP-25, it is not the primary target of the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Option D. Synaptophysin: Synaptophysin is a synaptic vesicle membrane protein, but it is not directly involved in the SNARE complex or the process of exocytosis. It is not affected by the tetanus neurotoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical students should understand that in tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin targets and affects synaptobrevin (VAMP), disrupting the SNARE complex and inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis. This knowledge is important for understanding the pathophysiology of tetanus.

 

The light chain of tetanospasmin cleave the Gln76-Phe77 bond of synaptobrevin which is an integral V-SNARE necessary for vesicle fusion to membranes in CNS and thus by cleaving this SNARE, TeNT has the effect of interfering with exocytosis of neurotransmitters such as γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glycine from inhibitory interneurons causing violent spastic paralysis.

 

Ref- Ananthanarayan and Paniker 10th e/p 265

questions.text: The significance of HMP shunt are all except? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Utilizes ribose

 

Explanation:

 

The Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) shunt, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP), has several significant roles:

 

Option A. Source of NADPH: The HMP shunt produces NADPH in its oxidative phase. NADPH is essential for various biosynthetic reactions, including fatty acid synthesis and maintaining the reduced state of glutathione in red blood cells.

 

Option B. Source of ribose 5 phosphate: At the end of the oxidative phase, ribulose 5-phosphate is produced, which can be further converted into ribose 5-phosphate. Ribose 5-phosphate is a crucial precursor for the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

Option C. Source of acetyl CoA: One of the end products of the HMP shunt is glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate, which can enter glycolysis. Through glycolysis, it can eventually form pyruvate, which can be converted into acetyl CoA in the presence of oxygen.

 

Option D. Utilizes ribose: This statement is incorrect as the HMP shunt primarily produces ribose 5-phosphate rather than utilizing it. Ribose 5-phosphate is a significant product of this pathway and is used in the synthesis of nucleotides and nucleic acids.

 

The overall reaction of the HMP shunt can be summarized as:

 

3G-6-P+6NADP+→2G-6-P+Glyceraldehyde-3-P+3CO2+6NADPH

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HMP shunt is significant for producing NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate and indirectly contributing to the formation of acetyl CoA, but it does not utilize ribose.

questions.text: Inhibitor A and B are: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive and non-competitive

 

Inhibitor A is a competitive inhibitor, and Inhibitor B is a non-competitive inhibitor.

 

  • Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A): In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme. This means that increasing the concentration of the substrate can overcome the inhibition. In this scenario, the maximum velocity (Vmax) of the reaction remains unchanged because, at high substrate concentrations, the enzyme can still achieve its maximum rate. However, the apparent affinity of the enzyme for the substrate decreases, leading to an increase in the Michaelis constant (Km). On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the y-axis, which represents no change in Vmax but a change in Km.
  • Non-Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B): Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an allosteric site rather than the active site, and their binding is not affected by the substrate concentration. As a result, the inhibition cannot be overcome by adding more substrate. Non-competitive inhibition leads to a decrease in the Vmax because the inhibitor reduces the overall number of active enzymes. However, Km remains unchanged because the binding of the inhibitor does not affect the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, non-competitive inhibition is indicated by lines that intersect on the x-axis, reflecting no change in Km but a decrease in Vmax.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uncompetitive and non-competitive: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme. This binding decreases both Km and Vmax because the inhibitor effectively removes some enzyme-substrate complexes from the reaction. This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A shows characteristics of competitive inhibition, not uncompetitive inhibition.

 

Option C. Non-competitive and uncompetitive: This option is incorrect because Inhibitor A is competitive, not non-competitive, and Inhibitor B is non-competitive, not uncompetitive. Therefore, this combination does not accurately represent the inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B.

 

Option D. Non-competitive and competitive: This option is incorrect because it reverses the correct inhibition types for Inhibitor A and B. Inhibitor A is competitive, while Inhibitor B is non-competitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember that competitive inhibitors increase Km but do not change Vmax, while non-competitive inhibitors decrease Vmax but do not change Km.

questions.text: dd-NTPs in Sanger’s Sequencing technique uses? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Termination of polymerase

 

  • The correct answer is C. ddNTPs are used in Sanger's Sequencing because they lack the 3'-OH group required for the formation of the phosphodiester bond during DNA strand elongation. When a ddNTP is incorporated into the growing DNA strand by DNA polymerase, it causes termination of DNA synthesis because the next nucleotide cannot be added due to the absence of the 3'-OH group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its fluorescence: ddNTPs in Sanger's Sequencing are not primarily used for their fluorescence. While modern Sanger Sequencing methods may incorporate fluorescence for detection, ddNTPs themselves are not inherently fluorescent.

 

Option B. DNA polymerization: ddNTPs do not contribute to DNA polymerization in the same way as regular dNTPs (deoxynucleotide triphosphates). Regular dNTPs are used by DNA polymerase to extend the DNA strand, while ddNTPs have a unique property that leads to their specific role in sequencing.

 

Option D. Removal of primer: ddNTPs are not involved in the removal of primers in Sanger's Sequencing. Primer removal typically occurs after the sequencing reaction is complete and is not directly related to the role of ddNTPs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dideoxy nucleotides are nucleotides in which O from 2’ and 3’ position of sugar is absent. These nucleotides, if inserted in the growing DNA chains will cause termination of polymerization as DNA polymerase will not be able to perform catalyzation of formation of Phosphodiester bond. This form the basis for a DNA sequencing technique know as Sanger DNA sequencing aka chain termination method.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 439

choices.text: If a and c are correct
If a, b and c are correct
a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion
  2. Glucose: facilitated diffusion
  3. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport
  4. Na: Secondary Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

 

Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.

 

Option C. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:

  1. Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  2. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.

 

Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium often moves down its gradient, but it is also involved in secondary active transport to drive uptake of other substances against their gradients (e.g., glucose in intestines).
The Na⁺/glucose symporter (SGLT) is a classic example.
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-639

choices.text: Decrease scavanging of RBC by macrophages

questions.text: What is seen in G6PD deficiency? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease generation of reduced glutathione

 

G6PD deficiency results in reduced production of reduced glutathione (GSH), an important antioxidant in red blood cells. This decrease in GSH levels impairs the cell's ability to neutralize harmful reactive oxygen species (ROS) and, as a result, increases oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease membrane lipid peroxidation: G6PD deficiency can lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione levels, which normally help protect red blood cell membranes from oxidative damage. Therefore, a deficiency in G6PD can actually increase membrane lipid peroxidation, making red blood cells more susceptible to damage from oxidative stress.

 

Option C. Decrease NADH generation: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the production of NADPH (not NADH), which is essential for the regeneration of reduced glutathione and the maintenance of antioxidant defenses in red blood cells. NADPH is crucial in protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

 

Option D. Decrease scavenging of RBC by macrophages: G6PD deficiency can actually increase the susceptibility of red blood cells to phagocytosis by macrophages. The oxidative stress and damage to red blood cells caused by G6PD deficiency can lead to the removal of these damaged cells by macrophages, causing hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells).

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency is associated with a decrease in the generation of reduced glutathione , leading to increased oxidative stress and susceptibility of red blood cells to damage and hemolysis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 185-186

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to inhibition of: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PDH (Pyruvate dehydrogenase)

 

Thiamine deficiency affects the activity of PDH, which is an enzyme complex responsible for converting pyruvate (a product of glycolysis) into acetyl-CoA, a key molecule in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When PDH is inhibited, pyruvate cannot enter the citric acid cycle, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate, which is then converted to lactic acid, resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is not directly related to lactic acidosis in the context of thiamine deficiency. Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which can be used in various metabolic pathways.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK): PEPCK is involved in gluconeogenesis, a metabolic pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. It does not directly contribute to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme involved in the final step of glycolysis, where it catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not directly associated with lactic acidosis due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is the enzyme affected in a patient with thiamine deficiency who develops lactic acidosis.

 

 

Enzyme performing oxidative decarboxylation need vitamin B1 for their reaction. Some examples are:

  1. PDH
  2. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Additional Information:

  • Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity
  • Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6
  • Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity

questions.text: What is the order of drawing blood sample in vials/vacutainers: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey

 

Explanation:

 

Order of Draw in Blood Collection (Vacutainer Method)

 

The standard order of draw is important to avoid cross-contamination of additives between tubes, which can affect lab results.

 

Here’s the correct order based on CLSI (Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute) guidelines:

 

  1. Blood culture bottles (if needed)
  2. Light Blue – contains sodium citrate (for coagulation tests like PT, aPTT)
  3. Red / Gold / SST – no additive or clot activator (for serum tests)
  4. Green – contains heparin (for plasma chemistry)
  5. Lavender / Pink – contains EDTA (for hematology, e.g., CBC)
  6. Grey – contains sodium fluoride + potassium oxalate (for glucose and lactate)

 

So, the correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue, Red, Lavender, Grey.

 

1. Blue: The blue-top tube is typically used for coagulation tests that require blood to be collected in citrate anticoagulant. The citrate in the tube helps prevent blood clotting by binding calcium.

 

2. Red: The red-top tube does not contain any anticoagulant and is commonly used for collecting blood samples for various tests, including serum chemistry, blood bank, and serology. After allowing the blood to clot, it is centrifuged, and the resulting serum is used for analysis.

 

3. Lavender: The lavender-top tube contains EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) as an anticoagulant. It is used for collecting whole blood for complete blood count (CBC), blood typing, and other hematological tests. EDTA helps preserve the blood cell morphology.

 

4. Grey: The grey-top tube contains an anticoagulant called potassium oxalate or sodium fluoride. It is used primarily for glucose testing and helps preserve blood glucose levels by inhibiting glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of drawing blood samples in vials/vacutainers is Blue (coagulation tests), Red (serum tests), Lavender (hematology tests), and Grey (glucose tests) to ensure accurate test results and avoid cross-contamination.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Explanation:

 

Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.

 

 

C banding: stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.

 

Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.

 

Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.

 

Note –  Q banding: uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

 

Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin-B12 dependent enzymes? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Methylmalonyl Co isomerase
  2. Homocysteine synthase
  3. Folate reductase
  4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 only

 

Among the given enzymes, methyl malonyl Co isomerase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12 dependent enzymes.

 

Physiologic role of B12 –

 

  1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase: D-Methyl malonyl CoA is formed in the body from propionyl CoA. It is then converted to L form by a racemase and then isomerized by methylmalonyl-CoA mutase (containing Ado-B12) to succinyl CoA, which enters into citric acid cycle. In B12 deficiency, methylmalonyl CoA accumulates and methyl malonic aciduria occurs.
  2. Homocysteine Methyl Transferase requires B12 activity to convert homocysteine to methionine.
  3. Methyl Folate Trap and Folate Deficiency - The production of methyl THFA is an irreversible step. Therefore, the only way for regeneration of free THFA is step No. 1 in Figure. When B12 is deficient, this reaction cannot take place. This is called the methyl folate trap. This leads to the associated folic acid scarcity in B12 deficiency.

 

 

Vitamin B12-dependent Enzymes:

 

1. Methylmalonyl CoA Isomerase (Methylmalonyl CoA mutase): This enzyme converts methylmalonyl CoA to succinyl CoA, a critical step in the catabolism of certain amino acids and fatty acids. The enzyme requires adenosylcobalamin (Ado-B12) as a cofactor.

 

4. Methionine Synthase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine using methylcobalamin (Me-B12) as a cofactor. This reaction is crucial for the regeneration of methionine and the production of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), an essential methyl group donor in numerous methylation reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Homocysteine Synthase: There is no enzyme by this specific name, but homocysteine is converted to methionine by methionine synthase, which is vitamin B12-dependent.

 

3. Folate Reductase: This enzyme reduces dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), an essential step in folate metabolism. However, it does not require vitamin B12 as a cofactor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enzymes methylmalonyl CoA isomerase and methionine synthase are dependent on vitamin B12. These enzymes play critical roles in metabolic pathways, including amino acid catabolism and methylation reactions.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text:
Korsakoff psychosis is true except? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Ataxia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis is a chronic neurological condition often associated with long-term alcohol abuse leading to vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency. The condition is characterized by severe memory issues, particularly anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories) and confabulation (fabrication of memories to fill in gaps in recollection). Patients may also experience retrograde amnesia (loss of pre-existing memories).

 

  • Amnesia: This is a hallmark symptom of Korsakoff psychosis. Patients have significant difficulty forming new memories and may lose some of their older memories.
  • Confabulation: Another key feature, where patients unknowingly create false memories to fill in the gaps of their amnesia. These fabricated memories are often a mix of true events and imagination but are presented by the patient as genuine recollections.

 

Other options:

 

  • Ophthalmoplegia: This condition, characterized by paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles, is not a feature of Korsakoff psychosis but rather of Wernicke's encephalopathy, the acute phase that can precede Korsakoff syndrome if left untreated.
  • Ataxia: Like ophthalmoplegia, ataxia (lack of voluntary coordination of muscle movements) is a symptom of Wernicke's encephalopathy rather than Korsakoff psychosis. Ataxia affects the patient's gait and movement, but it is not present in the chronic Korsakoff stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is primarily characterized by amnesia and confabulation, not by ophthalmoplegia or ataxia, which are associated with the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy phase of thiamine deficiency

choices.text: Differential mRNA processing

questions.text: Affinity maturation of antibodies is because of? ((INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Somatic hypermutation

 

Option A. Somatic hypermutation: Affinity maturation primarily occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes and spleen. The cause of affinity maturation is Somatic hypermutation.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Differential mRNA Processing: This process involves chemical modification of mRNA during mRNA processing. While it is important for generating diversity in certain proteins, it is not directly related to affinity maturation of antibodies.

 

Option C. CD40: CD40 is a co-stimulatory molecule involved in B cell activation. It plays a role in the interaction between B cells and T cells. While it is important for various aspects of immune response, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Option D. Gene Rearrangements: Gene rearrangements, specifically V(D)J recombination, occur during the early development of B cells. This process creates diversity in the variable regions of antibody genes. While important for generating initial antibody diversity, it is not the primary cause of affinity maturation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Affinity maturation is a process by which antibodies undergo modifications to enhance their binding affinity for a specific antigen over time. This is crucial for the adaptive immune system to generate more effective and specific immune responses.

 

Somatic Hypermutation (SHM):

Definition: Somatic hypermutation is a process that introduces point mutations into the variable regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells.

 

Location: It occurs in the germinal centers of secondary lymphoid organs during the B cell response to an antigen.

 

Purpose: The primary goal of somatic hypermutation is to introduce random mutations in the variable regions of the immunoglobulin genes, leading to a diverse set of antibodies with different binding affinities.

 

Outcome: B cells that produce antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen are selectively favored and survive, while those with lower affinity may undergo apoptosis.

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step → RT-PCR
  • Second step → Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

questions.text: Xanthurenic Acid in urine indicates: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6 deficiency

 

Xanthurenic assay a.k.a. Tryptophan load test. Xanthurenic acid in urine indicates Vitamin B6 deficiency. Xanthurenic acid is a metabolite that is formed during the breakdown of the amino acid tryptophan. Under normal conditions, tryptophan is metabolized along the kynurenine pathway, which involves the conversion of tryptophan to various intermediate compounds. One of these intermediates is xanthurenic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase activity, thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) effect, and blood thiamine levels.

 

Option C. Niacin deficiency: Measurement of urinary N-methylnicotinamide (NMN) excretion, and niacin load test.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2 deficiency: Measurement of erythrocyte glutathione reductase activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with a deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine), the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (vitamin B3) is impaired. As a result, tryptophan is metabolized through an alternative pathway, leading to the accumulation of xanthurenic acid. Therefore, the presence of xanthurenic acid in urine is indicative of a vitamin B6 deficiency.

questions.text: In Pompe’s disease, enzyme deficiency is? (INICET May 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase

 

Pompe's disease, also known as glycogen storage disease type II or acid maltase deficiency, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or absence of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase (also called acid alpha-glucosidase or acid maltase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen, a complex sugar molecule, into glucose within the lysosomes of cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in the regulation of glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that breaks down glucose to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

Option C. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase: Muscle glycogen phosphorylase is an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of glycogen in muscle tissue. Its deficiency causes McArdle’s disease.

 

Option D. Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme involved in the conversion of lactate, a byproduct of anaerobic metabolism, back into pyruvate, which can enter the citric acid cycle for further energy production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In individuals with Pompe's disease, the deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha glucosidase leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly the muscles. This glycogen buildup affects the proper functioning of cells and tissues, causing a wide range of symptoms, primarily affecting the muscles and respiratory system.

questions.text: Which of the following is not glucogenic?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acetyl coenzyme A

 

  • Acetyl CoA is not glucogenic. It enters the citric acid cycle (Kreb's cycle) for energy production and cannot be directly converted into glucose. It is primarily used for energy generation in the form of ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxaloacetate: Oxaloacetate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into glucose through a series of enzymatic reactions in the gluconeogenesis pathway. This makes it a precursor for glucose synthesis.

 

Option C. Lactate: Lactate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into pyruvate in the Cori cycle, and pyruvate can then be used in gluconeogenesis to produce glucose.

 

Option D. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a glucogenic compound. It serves as a central molecule in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, making it a key intermediate in the conversion of various substrates into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl CoA is not a glucogenic compound as it cannot be directly converted into glucose, unlike oxaloacetate, lactate, and pyruvate, which are glucogenic and contribute to glucose synthesis.

 

Substrates of gluconeogenesis (mostly 3C)                                                                                     

  1. Pyruvate (3C)
  2. Lactate (3C)                                                              
  3. Propionic acid (3C)
  4. Glycerol (3C)                                                       
  5. Glucogenic amino acids (18 amino acids)
  6. Both Ketogenic & Glucogenic amino acids
  7. Any TCA Intermediate (forms oxaloacetate which can enter gluconeogenesis)

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

 

  • RT-PCR is a molecular biology technique used to amplify and analyze RNA.
  • It involves the conversion of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcription, followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA.
  • RT-PCR is specifically used for RNA analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Western blotting is a technique used to detect and analyze proteins.
  • It involves the separation of proteins by gel electrophoresis and their subsequent transfer to a membrane for detection using antibodies specific to the protein of interest.
  • Western blotting primarily deals with proteins, not RNA.

 

Option C. Sanger's method (Sanger Sequencing):

  • Sanger sequencing is a DNA sequencing technique developed by Frederick Sanger.
  • It is used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA strands.
  • Sanger sequencing deals with DNA, not RNA.

 

Option D. G-banding:

  • G-banding is a cytogenetic staining technique used to visualize and analyze the banding patterns of chromosomes.
  • It is used in karyotyping and primarily focuses on the visualization of chromosomal DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sanger’s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.

 

Ref- Lehninger 6th e/p 331

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with Ewing sarcoma with ESWR1 gene mutation. The technique shown in the image was performed to confirm the diagnosis. Identify the technique shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluorescent in situ hybridization

 

The technique shown in the image is FISH demonstrating a positive EWSR1 gene rearrangement, characteristic of Ewing sarcoma.

 

The fused region denoted by Yellow corresponds to a normal intact gene, while a split signal pattern showing separate red and green signals is indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Karyotyping :

  • Karyotyping is a technique used to examine the number, size, and shape of chromosomes in a cell. While karyotyping can provide information about chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as specific as FISH in detecting the specific EWSR1 gene translocation associated with Ewing sarcoma.
  • Relevance: Karyotyping is a broader chromosome analysis technique and may not be the primary method for confirming Ewing sarcoma diagnosis.

 

Option C. Immunohistochemistry

  • Immunohistochemistry is a technique used to detect specific proteins in tissue samples. While it can be valuable in characterizing the tumor's protein expression, it may not directly confirm the presence of the EWSR1 gene mutation, which is a genetic abnormality.
  • Relevance: Immunohistochemistry can be used as a complementary technique to assess protein markers associated with Ewing sarcoma, but it may not be the primary method for confirming the genetic mutation.

 

Option D. Sanger's Technique

  •  Sanger sequencing is a method used for DNA sequencing. It is primarily used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA but may not be the technique of choice for confirming the specific EWSR1 gene mutation associated with Ewing sarcoma.
  • Relevance: Sanger sequencing is more focused on DNA sequence analysis rather than detecting gene translocations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situ hybridization is a modified version of DNA–DNA hybridization. If a metaphase spread chromosome preparation is probed with a gene, the location of the gene on a specific chromosome can be identified. The principle may be applied to histology slide also. In the tissue preparation, DNA is denatured, the specific probe tagged with fluorescent labels, incubated, washed and seen under a fluorescent (UV) microscope. The process is named as Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).

 

Applications of FISH are:

 

  1. Detects subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  2. Detects complex translocation
  3. Assessment of gene rearrangements in leukaemia
  4. Determination of amplification of HER2/neu in breast cancer
  5. Diagnosis of various types of lymphomas.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the Graph is suggestive of:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Michaelis Menten kinetics

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows a hyperbola which is suggestive of Michaels - Menten Kinetics of the enzyme.

 

Here, Vmax represents the maximum rate achieved by the system, happening at saturating substrate concentration for a given enzyme concentration. When the value of the Michaelis constant Km is numerically equal to the substrate concentration, then the reaction rate is half of Vmax. Biochemical reactions involving a single substrate are often assumed to follow Michaelis–Menten kinetics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allosteric Activation: This typically results in a sigmoid (S-shaped) curve rather than a hyperbolic one, as allosteric enzymes exhibit cooperative binding.

 

Option B. Cooperative Binding: This is also characterized by a sigmoid curve, indicating that the binding of substrate to one active site affects the binding at other active sites.

 

Option D. Sigmoid Curve: This type of curve is associated with allosteric enzymes and cooperative binding, not with Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Michaelis-Menten kinetics is characterized by a hyperbolic curve where Vmax is the maximum rate achieved, and Km is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax.

questions.text: Deamination of methylated cytosine will form: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymine

 

  • Deamination of methylated cytosine results in the conversion of cytosine to thymine. This process is important in DNA repair mechanisms and helps maintain the integrity of the genetic code. Thymine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and pairs with adenine in DNA base pairing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uracil: Uracil is not formed from the deamination of methylated cytosine. Uracil is one of the four standard nucleobases in RNA and is not a product of cytosine deamination.

 

Option B. Guanine: Guanine is another nucleobase and is not produced by the deamination of methylated cytosine.

 

Option C. Adenine: Adenine is one of the four standard nucleobases in DNA and RNA and is not the product of cytosine deamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymine is a pyrimidine. The structure of different pyrimidines can be shown as:

 

 

Now, it is clear from the figure below that if methylated cytosine is deaminated it will form thymine as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 323

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme:  (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiophorase

 

The liver lacks the enzyme thiophorase (succinyl-CoA:3-ketoacid CoA transferase) necessary to utilize the ketone bodies it produces. This enzyme is required to convert acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA, which can then be further metabolized into two molecules of acetyl-CoA. Acetyl-CoA is a central molecule in energy metabolism and can enter the citric acid cycle (also known as the Kreb’s cycle) to produce ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiolase: It is the common enzyme of Ketone body synthesis and KB utilization.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: HMG CoA synthase is RLE of ketone bodies synthesis in the liver. It is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG-CoA), a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol and ketone bodies. However, the absence of HMG CoA synthase would impact the overall synthesis of ketone bodies rather than their utilization.

 

Option D. HMG CoA reductase: HMG CoA reductase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of mevalonate, which is a precursor molecule in the production of cholesterol.
