However, the absence of HMG CoA reductase in the liver would not directly affect the utilization of ketone bodies. It would primarily impact the synthesis of cholesterol and other downstream products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

 

  • Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids. They consist of three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol molecule. These molecules are hydrophobic and do not have a polar or hydrophilic region. Triglycerides are the primary storage form of energy in the body and are commonly found in adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglycerol: Phosphoglycerol, also known as phosphoglyceride or glycerophospholipid, is an amphipathic lipid. It has a polar phosphate head group and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Phosphoglycerides are essential components of cell membranes, where they form the lipid bilayer.

 

Option C. Glycolipids: Glycolipids are amphipathic lipids. They have a hydrophilic carbohydrate (sugar) head group and hydrophobic lipid tails. Glycolipids are important in cell membranes, particularly in nerve cells and the myelin sheath. They play a role in cell signaling and recognition.

 

Option D. Sphingolipids: Sphingolipids are amphipathic lipids. They consist of a sphingosine backbone, a hydrophilic head group (usually containing a sugar), and one or two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Sphingolipids are crucial components of cell membranes and are involved in various cellular processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.

 

They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

choices.text: Mono-unsaturated fatty acids
Poly-unsaturated fatty acids

questions.text: Which require maximum energy for assimilation? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Option A. Proteins:

  • Proteins are complex macromolecules consisting of amino acids.
  • They require a significant amount of energy for assimilation because the body needs to break them down into individual amino acids, which are then used for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbohydrates:

  • Carbohydrates are a primary source of energy for the body.
  • They are relatively easy to assimilate as they are broken down into glucose, which can be readily used for energy.

 

Option C. Mono-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Mono-unsaturated fatty acids are a type of dietary fat found in foods like olive oil and avocados.
  • They require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins because they can be broken down relatively easily and used for energy or stored as fat.

 

Option D. Poly-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Poly-unsaturated fatty acids, such as omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, are essential fats found in certain foods.
  • Similar to mono-unsaturated fatty acids, they require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteins require the maximum energy for assimilation among the options listed, as they need to be broken down into individual amino acids for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine

 

The question asks which of the listed options is not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids. To answer this, let's break down each of the options:

 

  • Dopamine is a well-known neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is first converted to DOPA, which then converts to dopamine. Dopamine plays various roles in the brain, including involvement in reward, motivation, and the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Tryptophan is converted into 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to form serotonin. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, sleep, and other functions.
  • GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate. The conversion of glutamate to GABA involves a decarboxylation reaction that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor. GABA plays a crucial role in reducing neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
  • Creatine, however, is not a neurotransmitter. While creatine is synthesized from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine, it functions primarily as a molecule that helps to supply energy to cells, particularly muscle cells, by regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). Creatine is not involved in neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine.

 

Option B. Serotonin: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tryptophan.

 

Option C. GABA: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for the breakdown of triglycerides stored in adipose tissue into fatty acids and glycerol. When insulin levels are high, such as after a meal, it promotes fat storage and inhibits HSL activity, reducing the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoprotein lipase: Insulin activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of lipoproteins, specifically in the hydrolysis of triglycerides in circulating chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). Insulin promotes LPL activity, which facilitates the uptake of fatty acids into adipose tissue and muscle for storage and energy utilization.

 

Option C. Acid lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on acid lipase. Acid lipase enzymes, such as gastric lipase and lysosomal lipase, function in different environments and processes compared to the regulation of lipids by insulin in the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Alkaline lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on alkaline lipase. Alkaline lipases are typically found in the pancreas and function in the digestion of dietary fats. They are not directly regulated by insulin in the same way as the lipases involved in adipose tissue and circulating lipoprotein metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state. Understanding the regulatory role of insulin in lipase enzymes is essential for medical students. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to promote fat storage and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) to facilitate fatty acid uptake, which helps maintain energy homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the body.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 240, 245

questions.text: Congenital lactic acidosis is due to the defect of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Congenital lactic acidosis occurs when there is an accumulation of lactic acid in the body from birth, often due to a metabolic defect. In normal metabolism, glucose is converted to pyruvate through glycolysis. Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is transported into the mitochondria, where it is converted into acetyl-CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. Acetyl-CoA then enters the Krebs cycle to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

When there is a deficiency or defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA. As a result, pyruvate accumulates and is instead converted to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis. Since this condition is present from birth, it is termed congenital lactic acidosis. Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is one of the key causes of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transketolase: This enzyme plays a role in the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt) and is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate or the production of lactic acid. Defects in transketolase do not lead to congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids and its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease, not congenital lactic acidosis. It is unrelated to pyruvate metabolism.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the Krebs cycle, catalyzing the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. While it is involved in cellular respiration, defects in this enzyme are not responsible for congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a key cause of congenital lactic acidosis, as it prevents the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to an accumulation of lactic acid.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

choices.text: Droplet digital PCR

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Droplet digital PCR

 

Option A. Droplet digital PCR : Digital Droplet PCR (ddPCR) is known as the third generation of quantitative PCR and is the Best method for detection of mutation with low allele frequency.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH): FISH is a cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences. While it is valuable for detecting chromosomal abnormalities, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting mutations at low allele frequencies.

 

Option C. Nested PCR: Nested PCR involves two rounds of PCR amplification, with the second round using primers nested within the product of the first round. While it can increase sensitivity, it may not be as quantitative or precise as ddPCR.

 

Option D. Sanger Sequencing: Sanger sequencing is a traditional DNA sequencing method. While it is highly accurate, it may not be as sensitive as ddPCR for detecting low-frequency mutations. It is more suitable for identifying mutations present at higher allele frequencies.

 

Educational objective:

 

Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR)

 

Principle: Droplet digital PCR is a highly sensitive and quantitative method for detecting and quantifying nucleic acids. It partitions the PCR reaction into thousands of droplets, and each droplet serves as an individual reaction chamber.

 

Advantages: It allows for absolute quantification of DNA with high precision and sensitivity. It is particularly effective in detecting mutations present at low allele frequencies.

 

Application: ddPCR is widely used for detecting rare mutations, monitoring minimal residual disease, and assessing low-abundance targets in various samples.

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Option B. Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
  • Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Without adequate vitamin C, collagen production is impaired, leading to the characteristic symptoms of scurvy, including impaired wound healing and gum bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beri-Beri:

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Thiamine deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option C. Night Blindness:

  • Night blindness is often associated with a deficiency in vitamin A (retinol).
  • Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option D. Rickets:

  • Rickets is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Vitamin D plays a role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which is crucial for bone health but does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.

 

Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.

 

 

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.

 

Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.

questions.text:
True regarding mitochondrial DNA? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

  1. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome
  2. Single stranded Circular DNA
  3. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
  4. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins
  5. Has around 16,000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, C, E

 

MITOCHONDRIAL DNA         

 

Statement A. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome: mtDNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA due to the lack of introns and protective histone proteins, which help prevent mutations in nuclear DNA.

 

Statement C. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons: mtDNA uses a slightly different genetic code. For example, the codon UGA, which is a stop codon in the universal genetic code, codes for tryptophan in mtDNA. Similarly, AGG and AGA code for arginine in the universal genetic code but are stop codons in mtDNA. AUA codes for isoleucine in the universal genetic code but codes for methionine in mtDNA.

 

 

Statement E. Has around 16,000 base pairs: mtDNA contains approximately 16,000 base pairs and 37 genes, which make up about 1% of the total cellular DNA.

                                   

Other Statements:

 

Statement B. Single stranded Circular DNA: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA is circular but double-stranded.

 

Statement D. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA encodes for only 13 of the 67 proteins required for the electron transport chain (ETC), which is approximately 19% of the total.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA, has a slightly different genetic code, and contains around 16,000 base pairs, encoding for a portion but not all of the proteins required for the electron transport chain.

questions.text: Which of the following supplement is required more for a lactating woman than the pregnant female? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Vitamin A


During lactation, the mother's body requires additional nutrients to support breast milk production, which provides all necessary nutrients for the growing infant. Some nutrient needs increase more during lactation than pregnancy.

 

Comparison of Nutritional Requirements:

 

Vitamin A:

Needed for:

  • Infant vision development
  • Immune function
  • Epithelial integrity

Significantly increased loss through breast milk

Hence, greater requirement in lactation than pregnancy

 

Others options:


B12, Calcium, and Thiamine requirements increase only slightly or remain the same.

Vitamin A shows the most significant increase.

 

Educational Objective: 

Vitamin A is required more for a lactating woman than a pregnant female. This increased need ensures that there is enough vitamin A in breast milk to support the baby's growth and development, particularly for their immune system and vision.

questions.text: Uracil was found in genetic code. Which vitamin deficiency leads to this condition:(INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Folate

 

  • Folate deficiency is the correct answer. Folate (also known as vitamin B9) plays a crucial role in DNA synthesis and repair. When there is a deficiency in folate, it can lead to the misincorporation of Uracil into DNA, causing DNA instability and other genetic abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12: A deficiency in vitamin B12 is not directly associated with the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B12 deficiency primarily affects red blood cell production and neurological functions.

 

Option B. B6: A deficiency in vitamin B6 is also not directly related to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin B6 deficiency can lead to various neurological symptoms but does not cause Uracil incorporation into DNA.

 

Option D. Vit E: Vitamin E deficiency does not lead to the presence of Uracil in the genetic code. Vitamin E is primarily known for its antioxidant properties and its role in maintaining cell membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic code is related to DNA, but DNA do not contain Uracil. In pyrimidine synthesis, UMP is the first pyrimidine nucleotide to be synthesized and other two pyrimidines thymine and Cytosine are synthesized from it. Uracil to cytosine conversion requires amino group addition provided by glutamine. Uracil is converted to thymine by enzyme thymidylate synthase by methylation where methyl group is donated by methyl-THF. So, a deficiency Folate will result in thymine deficiency and may lead to uracil appearing in the DNA in place of thymine.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 333

questions.text: Match the following transporters with the molecule they carry. (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1c, 2d, 3a, 4b

 

Hemopexin transports free heme. Haptoglobin binds to and transports hemoglobin. Pre-albumin, also known as transthyretin, transports thyroxin and retinol binding protein. Albumin transports various hydrophobic substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and many drugs. The correct match is:

 

  1. Hemopexin - c. Heme
    Hemopexin specifically binds and transports free heme to prevent its oxidative damage.
  2. Haptoglobin - d. Hemoglobin
    Haptoglobin binds to free hemoglobin released from erythrocytes, preventing loss of iron and kidney damage.
  3. Pre-albumin - a. Thyroxin
    Pre-albumin (transthyretin) transports thyroxin (T4) and retinol-binding protein.
  4. Albumin - b. Free fatty acid
    Albumin transports a wide range of substances, including free fatty acids, bilirubin, steroid hormones, and various drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match can be given as:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 630-631

questions.text: RBC uses which of the following substances during fasting/starvation? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucose

 

Under normal physiological conditions, RBCs rely on glucose as their main energy source. Glucose is metabolized through the glycolytic pathway within RBCs to produce ATP, which is essential for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of red blood cells. RBCs lack mitochondria, so they exclusively use anaerobic glycolysis to generate energy from glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ketones: RBCs do not utilize ketones as a significant energy source. Ketones are typically used by other tissues like the brain and muscles during prolonged fasting or starvation when glucose levels are low.

 

Option C. Amino acids: While amino acids can be used as an energy source by some tissues during fasting or starvation, RBCs primarily rely on glucose and do not extensively use amino acids for energy production.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: RBCs do not use fatty acids as their primary energy source during fasting or starvation. Fatty acid metabolism primarily occurs in tissues with mitochondria, and RBCs lack these organelles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RBCs always uses glucose whether it is fed state or fasting/starvation state because RBCs lack mitochondria. As ketone body utilization and fatty acid oxidation both take place in mitochondria so, RBCs cannot use fatty acids & ketone bodies as energy source.

 

Table: Substrates utilized for energy production

 

 

  • Fetal heart and also in case of heart failure, main fuel is Glucose.
  • Brain cannot use FA as FAs cannot cross blood brain barrier.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/p 138-139

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 3

 

Explanation:

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3

 

Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.

 

Other tests

 

Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.

 

The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.

 

Test 2: Shows the heat coagulation test. The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

questions.text: Highest thermic effect?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Proteins have the highest thermic effect among the three macronutrients. When you consume protein-rich foods, your body needs to expend more energy to break down and process the proteins. This is because proteins are composed of amino acids, and the body requires energy to convert them into usable forms. The thermic effect of proteins ranges from 20% to 30% of the total caloric intake from protein.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carbohydrates: Carbohydrates have a moderate thermic effect. The thermic effect of carbohydrates ranges from 5% to 10% of the total caloric intake from carbohydrates.

 

Option C. Fats: Fats have the lowest thermic effect among the macronutrients. The thermic effect of fats ranges from 0% to 5% of the total caloric intake from fats.

 

Option D. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are the building blocks of fats, and their thermic effect is similar to that of fats.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thermic effect of food (TEF) refers to the increase in energy expenditure that occurs during the digestion, absorption, and metabolism of nutrients in the body. This effect varies depending on the macronutrient composition of the food consumed.

questions.text:
Ketosis is common in type 1 DM due to: (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Decreased beta-oxidation of fatty acids

2. Increased mobilization of fat from the adipose cell

3. Decreased acetyl Co in TCA cycle

4. Increased beta-hydroxy butyrate synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2, 3 and 4

 

2, 3 and 4 statements correctly explain the reason behind increased ketogenesis as seen in type1 DM.

 

In Type 1 DM insulin is deficient and GLUT4 (insulin-dependent uptake) mediated glucose uptake is not possible in the heart or skeletal muscles. So, fat is mobilized from adipose tissue for energy.

 

 

The following points explain the reasons behind increased ketogenesis:

 

Statement 2: Increased Mobilization of Fat from the Adipose Cell: In type 1 DM, insulin deficiency leads to increased lipolysis in adipose tissue, resulting in the release of free fatty acids into the bloodstream. These fatty acids are transported to the liver, where they undergo beta-oxidation.

Statement 3: Decreased Acetyl CoA in the TCA Cycle: Insulin deficiency also leads to reduced availability of oxaloacetate in the liver, which is diverted to gluconeogenesis. This decreases the entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, causing an accumulation of acetyl CoA.

Statement 4: Increased Beta-Hydroxybutyrate Synthase: The increased concentration of acetyl CoA leads to the synthesis of ketone bodies, including beta-hydroxybutyrate. The enzyme beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of acetoacetate to beta-hydroxybutyrate.

 

Other Statements:

  • Decreased Beta-Oxidation of Fatty Acids (1): This is incorrect. In type 1 DM, beta-oxidation of fatty acids is actually increased due to the elevated levels of free fatty acids resulting from enhanced lipolysis.

 

Additional Context:

In the absence of insulin, glucose uptake by cells is impaired, leading to increased lipolysis and subsequent beta-oxidation of fatty acids. The resulting acetyl CoA cannot enter the TCA cycle efficiently due to low levels of oxaloacetate, leading to the production of ketone bodies (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone).

 

Educational Objective

 

Ketosis in type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by increased mobilization of fat from adipose tissue, decreased entry of acetyl CoA into the TCA cycle, and increased production of ketone bodies, particularly beta-hydroxybutyrate.

questions.text: Most radio-resistant phase of cell cycle? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S

 

This is the synthesis phase, where DNA replication occurs. Cells in S phase are considered the most radio-resistant because they have already duplicated their genetic material, making them less susceptible to radiation-induced damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G1 (Gap 1) Phase: Cells in the G1 phase are generally sensitive to radiation because they are actively engaged in normal metabolic activities and are preparing for DNA synthesis in the subsequent S phase.

 

Option C. G2 (Gap 2) Phase: The G2 phase is a period of further preparation for cell division (mitosis). Quite radiosensitive, due to checkpoint activation.

 

Option D. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where cell division occurs, and the cell divides into two daughter cells. Cells in M phase are most sensitive to radiation.

questions.text: Which amino acid is not used for synthesis of hormones?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycine

 

Glycine is an amino acid that does not directly participate in the synthesis of hormones. While glycine is an important amino acid involved in many biological processes, including the synthesis of proteins, it is not a precursor for hormone synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of several important hormones, including thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine), catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine), and melanin.

 

Option B. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine in the body and, as a result, indirectly contributes to hormone synthesis. Tyrosine, derived from phenylalanine, is then used for the synthesis of various hormones.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that serves as a precursor for the synthesis of serotonin and melatonin, both of which are important hormones involved in regulating mood, sleep, and other physiological processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosine, phenylalanine, and tryptophan are all aromatic amino acids that serve as building blocks for the synthesis of various hormones.

questions.text: Sideroblastic anemia can be treated by?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans A) Pyridoxine

 

Option A. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine, also known as vitamin B6, can be effective in treating certain forms of sideroblastic anemia, particularly those associated with a deficiency in pyridoxine-dependent enzymes. It helps improve heme synthesis and reduce the accumulation of iron in the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B1: Vitamin B1, also known as thiamine, is not typically used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia. Thiamine deficiency can lead to other conditions, such as beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it is not directly related to sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. B3: Vitamin B3, also known as niacin, is not typically used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia. Niacin deficiency can lead to pellagra but is not directly associated with this type of anemia.

 

Option D. B12: Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is essential for the production of red blood cells and is used in the treatment of megaloblastic anemias, such as those caused by vitamin B12 deficiency or folate deficiency. It is not a primary treatment for sideroblastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sideroblastic anemia can be treated with Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation, which helps improve heme synthesis and reduce iron accumulation in red blood cell precursors.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 310

choices.text: Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.
﻿﻿﻿Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.text: Which of the following is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

 

“Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased is false. 

 

This process occurs in the TCA (Krebs) cycle and is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, a mitochondrial enzyme.


In advanced liver disease, alpha-ketoglutarate is diverted toward glutamate and glutamine synthesis (to help detoxify ammonia), which decreases its availability for the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate is true. In liver disease, there is an increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate as a way to detoxify ammonia. 

 

Option C. Decreased ATP synthesis is true. in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine. This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia is true. In advanced liver disease, the liver's ability to detoxify ammonia is compromised, leading to elevated ammonia levels in the bloodstream, resulting in hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Detoxification of ammonia takes place in the liver, where it is metabolised and excreted as urea (urea cycle). Due to impairment of ammonia metabolism in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine.

 

 

This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

questions.text: Binding site of miRNA on mRNA?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3’ UTR

 

  • This is the correct option.
  • miRNA binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA, leading to translational repression or mRNA degradation, thereby regulating gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5’ UTR (Untranslated Region):

  • This region is not typically the binding site for miRNA on mRNA.
  • miRNA primarily binds to the 3' UTR of mRNA to regulate gene expression.

 

Option C. Gene Promoter:

  • Gene promoters are regions involved in transcription initiation, not the binding sites for miRNA.

 

Option D.  Gene Body:

  • miRNA primarily targets the 3' UTR of mRNA, not the gene body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3’ UTR (Untranslated Region), where miRNA can regulate gene expression by binding and influencing mRNA stability or translation.

 

Ref - Lehninger 6th e/p 1081

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibitor in the graph?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Competitive inhibitor

 

Explanation:

 

This is a Lineweaver-Burk plot of enzyme kinetics, with 1/v (inverse of velocity) on the Y-axis and 1/[S] (inverse of substrate concentration) on the X-axis. The red line represents the inhibitor, and the blue line represents the normal substrate.

 

In the presence of a competitive inhibitor, the Km (Michaelis constant) increases while the Vmax (maximum velocity) remains unchanged. This is evident in the graph where the slope increases, indicating an increased Km, but the Y-intercept, representing 1/Vmax, stays the same.

 

For non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases while Km remains unchanged. This would be shown by an increase in the Y-intercept, which is not the case here.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-competitive inhibitor: In non-competitive inhibition, the Vmax decreases while the Km remains unchanged. This would be reflected in the graph by an increased Y-intercept (1/Vmax) while the slope remains the same, which is not observed here.

 

Option C. Allosteric inhibitor: Allosteric inhibitors bind to a site other than the active site and can either increase or decrease enzyme activity, affecting both Km and Vmax. The specific effects depend on the nature of the allosteric inhibition, which is not represented by the given Lineweaver-Burk plot.

 

Option D. Uncompetitive inhibitor: Uncompetitive inhibitors bind only to the enzyme-substrate complex, decreasing both Km and Vmax. This would be shown by parallel lines in the Lineweaver-Burk plot, which is not seen in the provided graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Competitive inhibitors increase the Km without affecting the Vmax, which is shown by an increase in the slope of the Lineweaver-Burk plot without changing the Y-intercept.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 77

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

 

  • The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code. Degeneracy means that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid. The third position of the codon (the wobble position) is less constrained and allows for some variation in the base pairing, which accommodates the degeneracy in the genetic code.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambiguity: Ambiguity is not a property of the codon but rather a state of uncertainty or multiple interpretations. In the genetic code, codons are specific and not ambiguous in their assignment to amino acids.

 

Option C. Universality: Universality refers to the fact that the genetic code is nearly identical in all living organisms. While universality is an important property of the genetic code, it is not directly related to the wobble hypothesis.

 

Option D. Commaless: "Commaless" is not a recognized property related to the codon or the wobble hypothesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.

 

Wobble bases

 

3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5’ to 3’ direction are wobble positions.

 

 

Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

choices.text: Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s
Ceruloplasmin - Hepatolenticular degeneration
High LDH1/LDH2 - Myocardial Infarction
Lipase - Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s

 

Option A. Defect in Beta glucocerebrosidase is associated with sphingolipid lysosomal storage disorder known as Gaucher’s disease Whereas Von Gierke’s disease is caused due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Hepatolenticular degeneration also known as Wilson’s disease is due to defect in ATP7B gene causing defective biliary excretion of copper and accumulation of copper in liver. There is decrease in plasma ceruloplasmin serving as marker.

 

Option C. In normal person, LDH-2 is more than LDH-1 in serum. BUT in myocardial infarction, LDH-1>>LDH-2. This is known as Flipped ratio of LDH in Myocardial Infarction.

 

Option D. Lipase and amylase are increased in plasma in case of Pancreatitis hence they serve as marker enzymes for pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Beta-glucocerebrosidase is linked to Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by a deficiency in Glucose-6-phosphatase. Correct pairing of diagnostic markers and associated conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 64, 167,634

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acrocentric

 

Explanation:

 

The marked chromosome is chromosome 13 and the type is acrocentric.

 

Each chromatid has a long arm “q” and a short arm “p” which are separated by a centromere.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have the centromere located in the center, creating arms of equal length. Examples include chromosomes 1 and 3.

 

Option C. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, creating one long arm and one short arm. Most human autosomes and the X chromosome are submetacentric.

 

Option D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have the centromere at the very end of the chromosome, creating only one arm. This type is not present in humans.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: In MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methionine

 

  • Methionine is not restricted in MSUD. MSUD is characterized by the inability to break down three specific branched-chain amino acids: Leucine, Isoleucine, and Valine. Methionine is not one of the amino acids that are restricted in the diet of individuals with MSUD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valine: Valine is one of the amino acids restricted in MSUD. People with MSUD need to limit their intake of Valine as their bodies cannot properly metabolize it.

 

Option C. Leucine: Leucine is another amino acid that is restricted in MSUD. It is one of the three branched-chain amino acids that individuals with MSUD need to limit in their diet.

 

Option D. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is also restricted in MSUD. Like Valine and Leucine, Isoleucine is a branched-chain amino acid that individuals with MSUD need to restrict to manage the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched Chain Keto-acid Decarboxylase resulting in defect in oxidative decarboxylation and catabolism of branched chain amino acids Valine, Isoleucine and leucine. As a result, these amino acids accumulate and are excreted in urine. So, for the treatment, these BCAA should be restricted in diet.

 

Methionine is a sulphur containing amino acid and do not require this enzyme for its metabolism. So, its restriction is not required in MSUD.  

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 290

questions.text: Brunt sugar smell of urine is due to the defect of? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Burnt sugar-like odour is a characteristic feature of Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD) which occurs due to the inherited deficiency of branched chain Keto-acid dehydrogenase/decarboxylase.
  • It results in a defect in oxidative phosphorylation and catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) Valine/Isoleucine/leucine. As a result, these amino acids are excreted in urine. There is also mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to phenylketonuria (PKU), which is characterized by a mousy or musty odor due to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites.

 

Option B. Isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase: Deficiency of isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase causes isovaleric acidemia, which is associated with a rancid, cheesy, or sweaty feet odor due to the accumulation of isovaleric acid.

 

Option C. Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase: Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase leads to tyrosinemia type I, which is characterized by a boiled cabbage or rotten mushrooms odor due to the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) K+

 

In the thick ascending loop of Henle, the maintenance of positive charge is primarily achieved through the recirculation of potassium ions (K+).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H+ (Hydrogen ions): Hydrogen ions play a role in regulating the pH of urine but are not primarily responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Option B. Na+ (Sodium ions): Sodium ions are actively reabsorbed in the thick ascending loop of Henle but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in this segment.

 

Option C. NH4+ (Ammonium ions): Ammonium ions are involved in acid-base regulation in the kidneys but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K+ is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K+ channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.

 

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase is activated by? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium

 

  • Glycogen phosphorylase is primarily activated indirectly by calcium ions. An increase in intracellular calcium levels triggers the activation of phosphorylase kinase, which, in turn, activates glycogen phosphorylase. Calcium acts as a secondary messenger to stimulate this cascade of enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose 6 Phosphate: Glucose 6-phosphate, a product of glycogenolysis (glycogen breakdown), actually inhibits glycogen phosphorylase. It is part of a negative feedback mechanism to prevent excessive glycogen breakdown when glucose levels are sufficient.

 

Option C. Insulin: Insulin does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. Instead, insulin plays a role in promoting glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase and inhibiting glycogen phosphorylase.

 

 

Option D. Glucose: Glucose itself does not directly activate glycogen phosphorylase. In fact, high levels of glucose signal that glucose is available for energy production, leading to the inhibition of glycogenolysis and glycogen phosphorylase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen phosphorylase is activated indirectly through the calcium signaling pathway, which initiates a series of enzymatic reactions ultimately leading to the activation of glycogen phosphorylase. This mechanism allows the regulation of glycogen breakdown in response to cellular energy needs.
